questiontext.text:
Two points \(P,Q\) have polar coordinates \([{@aa@},{@cc@}]\) and \([{@bb@},{@dd@}]\) respectively. By locating these points on a Cartesian plane find their equivalent Cartesian coordinates.

\(P(x, y) = (\)[[input:ans1]]\(,\) [[input:ans2]]\()\) [[validation:ans1]] [[validation:ans2]]

\(Q(x, y) = (\)[[input:ans3]]\(,\) [[input:ans4]]\()\) [[validation:ans3]] [[validation:ans4]]

generalfeedback.text:
From the key point, we know that \(x = r\cos\theta\) and \(y= r\sin\theta\). Substituting in the values from the question, we get that the polar coordinates \([{@aa@},{@cc@}]\) correspond to the Cartesian coordinates \(({@aa@}\cos{@cc@}, {@aa@}\sin{@cc@}) = ({@taPx@}, {@taPy@})\), and the polar coordinates \([{@bb@},{@dd@}]\) correspond to the Cartesian coordinates \(({@bb@}\cos{@dd@}, {@bb@}\sin{@dd@})= ({@taQx@}, {@taQy@})\). See the graph below for a visual representation of this:
